term_definitions.items: Additional contextual detail to be applied to all compositions.

The period of care to which this composition belongs. This equates to the CONTSYS concept and repesents an admisitrative or contractual spell of care, involving a specific instiution or care provider.
The identifier of the departmental period of care to which this Composition belongs.
Portlet ID from which stores the information where was the composition saved.
Psychological status of a patient as a part of nursing documentation
patient has distinct body odor, i.e. drunk, poor hygiene...
Fresh and/or healed - wounds and/or scars - multiple at least in one place
usual for other people's measures according to the occasion
Is patient wearing incompatible clothes / gaudy / flashy
patient is appropriately dressed for occasion
Is patient wearing sunglasses inside the building
Description of patient's piercings, i.e. unusual locations
Description of patient's tatoos, i.e. unusual images, locations
Does the patient retreat as to avoid touch/communication
Is the patient seductive/flirtatious in behaviour?
Is the patient suspicious towards nursing staff?
Does the patient show distant attitude?
Is the patient showing excessive friendliness?
Does the patient keep losing focus during conversation?
Is patient selective in choosing approipriate words?
Assessment of patient's perceptions, how the patient thinks
Leaps in thinking, leaps of thoughts
Patient's self-assessment, how the patient feels (mood and emotions)
Were there any past suicidal attempts by the patient (documented or reported in interview with the patient, others)?
Aspects of the patient's general appearance.
Patient does not have any problems with general apperance
Findings of eye assessment according to ZN documentation.
Impaired vision on the left eye.
Impaired vision in the right eye.
The position of the eyeball with respect to the orbit.
The eyeball appears to protrude from the orbit.
The eyeball position is normal with respect to the orbit.
The eyebell appears sunken in the orbit.
Vision is impaired in the left eye.
Vision is not impaired in the left eye.
Vision is impaired in the right eye.
Vision is not impaired in the right eye.
The eyelids are not syymetrical when closed.
The eyes do not appear red.
The eyes are responsive to light.
The eyes are not responsive to light.
Evidence of discharge from the eye. Abnormal discharge such as pus or blood-stained fluid is implied.
There is evidence of discharge from the eye.
There is no discharge from the eye.
Normal with correction of glasses or lens
Best motor response to stumulus in infant less than 2 years old.
Withdraws in response to painful stimulus.
Best verbal response to stimulus in a child older than 2 years.
Best verbal response to stimulus in a infant younger than 2 years.
Moans or groans, but no recognisable words.
Converses, but confused and disoriented in their environment.
Less than usual ability or spontaneous irritable cry.
The infant is alert babbles, coos or says words or sentences to their usual ability.
Best grimace response in response to pain. May be used instead of verbal response for intubated patients
Mild grimace or some change in facial expression to pain.
less than usual spontaneous ability or only responds to touch
Fifteen point scale used to assess the level of consciousness of a subject. Also known as the Modified Glasgow Coma Scale.
Fifteen point scale used to assess the level of consciousness of a child subject. Also known as the Modified Glasgow Coma Scale for Infants and Children.
Best verbal response to stimulus in an adult.
Best motor response to stimulus in child over 2 years old.
Opens eyes in response to painful stimuli in limbs.
Eyes open in response to pain
Opens eyes in response to any verbal approach.
Eyes open in response to speech
Moans or groans, but no recognisable words.
Intelligible speech, but no conversational exchange.
Converses, but confused and disoriented in their environment.
Localised movement in response to pain.
The sum of the 3 ordinal scores for each component parameter.
Eye Motor Verbal profile expressing each component individually. This can be derived as a combination of the preceding elements.
Not possible to test eye responses - for example in the case of associated severe facial/eye swelling or damage.
Not able to test eye response
Not possible to test verbal responses - for example in the case of associated intubation.
Not able to test verbal response
Not possible to test motor responses - for example in the case of associated limb paralysis.
Not able to test motor response
Comment about measurement of the Scale, especially if it was not possible to assess a response.
Reason for inability to test eye response.
Reason for inability to test eye response
Reason for inability to test verbal response.
Reason for inability to test verbal response
Reason for inability to test motor response.
Reason for inability to test motor response
Aditional tissue findings specific to gums
Differences from normal patient's voice, difficulties due to stomatitis
Incapable of speaking due to stomatitis
Doesn't speak for other reason than stomatitis (to young, deaf, doesn't want to speak)
Calculated level of stomatitis according to WHO. Level 0 means no stomatitis. (ian said it's ok, but could be ordinal)
Image, video or other multimedia elements
General or global assessment according to ZN documentation.
Visible skin color from fixed list.
The skin appears red, the colour of a blush.
Red (like blushing, but not restricted to face)
The skin apppears ashen or gray.
Pallor is restricted to the face.
Pallor is restricted to the fingers and toes.
Pallor is restricted to the extremities.
The temperature change applies to fingers and toes.
The temperature change applies to the left arm.
The temperature change applies to the right arm.
The temperature change applies to the left leg.
The temperature change applies to the right leg.
The temperature change applies to the whole body
The degree of swearing is normal.
Only the subject's head is sweaty.
Top of the fingers and toes
Top of the fingers and toes
The transcutaneous bilirubi is measured at forehead of infant
The transcutaneous bilirubi is measured at sternum of infant
The temperature change applies to peripherial parts of the body
The temperature change applies to central parth of the body
The temperature change applies to fingers and toes.
The temperature change applies to left arm
The temperature change applies to right arm
The temperature change applies to left leg
The temperature change applies to right leg
The temperature change applies to whole body
The temperature change applies to peripheral parts of the body
The temperature change applies to central parth of the body
How many hours patient has phototherapy
The pain is present when sitting
The pain is present when standing
The pain is present when walking.
The pain is present when lying.
The pain is present when resting.
The 6 faces pain scale was used.
The visual analogue score was used.
A pain tolerance measure was used.
A measure of activity was used.
The pain is associated with nausea.
The pain is associated with sleep disturbance.
The pain is associated with poor appetite.
The pain is associated with dimished physical activity.
The pain is associated with emotional upset.
The pain is associated with impaired concentration.
The pain is diffuse or widespread.
The pain has a crushing quality.
The pain has a burning quality.
The pain has a cramping quality.
The pain has a colicky quality.
The pain has a shooting quality.
The pain has a throbbing quality.
The pain has a heavy quality.
The pain has a tearing quality.
The pain has a squeezing quality.
The pain has a stabbing quality.
The pain has a griping quality.
Details of location and radiation of pain.
Description of location to where the pain radiates.
Level of pain on a 0-10 scale.
A symptom experienced by the patient.
Pain experienced by the patient, according to ZN documentation.
The symptom is present at times and not at others.
The symptom varys considerably but is almost always present.
The nature of the onset of the symptom.
Over a longer period of time.
The nature of the cessation of the symptom.
An event, activity or state that is associated with the symptom.
An event, activity or state that is associated with the symptom.
An event or activity that makes the symptom worse.
Information about a specific factor that changes the symptom.
An event or activity that modifies the symptom.
Other symptoms associated with this symptom.
Other symptoms associated with this symptom.
The duration of the symptom since onset.
The time (and/or date) of maximum intensity of the symptom.
The number of times this symptom has occurred during this episode.
Features of the course of the symptom.
The person has not had any significant experience of the symptom.
Over a short period of time.
The progress of the symptom relative to the past.
The symptom has improved over time.
The symptom is decreasing in intensity over time.
The symptom has not changed over time.
The symptom is increasing in intensity over time.
The symptom is getting worse over time.
The symptom has resolved over time.
Measures of the intensity of the symptom. Assumed to represent current intensity. Left unbounded to allow maximum, minimum and average intensities to be recorded.
The symptom is relieved by this factor.
The symptom is made better by this factor.
The symptom is somewhat improved by this factor.
The symptom is not modified by this factor.
The symptom is made somewhat worse by this factor.
The symptom is made worse by this factor.
The symptom is made much worse by this factor.
Details of previous symptoms and comparison to this episode.
Have there been any previous episodes of this symptom?
Text description of the course of the symptom over time.
A feature which would normally be expected but which is not present.
How the previous episode compares with this one.
Structured details of symptoms in previous episodes.
Details of locations in the body.
Link to a previous record of this symptom.
Short-lived and/or rapid onset of symptoms.
Acute episode on background of lon-standing symptom.
Detail of symptom formal scoring methods and results.
A text description of the symptom intensity.
The symptom is present on a cyclical basis.
The sympton is present on a seasonal basis.
The symptom presence or intensity fluctuates.
The symptom appears suddenly and dramatically.
The degree to which the symptom is bothering the patient.
The symptom is trivial and causes no problems.
The symptom does not interfere greatly with day to day activities.
The symptom interferes with day to day activities.
The symptom prohibits some key daily activities.
The symptom is almost maximum possible intensity and prohibits any activity.
The symptom is as bad as it can be.
Symptom severity score on a scale of 0-10.
A structure to collect information provided by the person or information provider in relation to the symptoms and difficulties they are presenting to the clinician
Base for recording the dates or intervals which apply
Presence of pressure ulcer; used also for quality control
Presence of edema (other terms: oedema, swelling)
appearance of waterly drops on the area
Presence of burning (stinging) pain at the area of skin lesion
Itching at the area of skin lesion
Presence of pain (any type of pain) at the area of skin lesion
Length between most distant points of the skin lesion
Width of skin lesion as a length measure perpendicular in regard to length of skin lesion.
Height of skin lesion above surround skin ; depth of skin lesion below surrounding skin
Level of skin lesion in regard to the surrounding skin
Presence of a blister or blisters
If a blister is squeezable, or if it can be pinched or crushed
Describe the content of a blister(s); maximum occurences are 2: blood + pus
hotter, warmer than the surrounding skin
same or approx. the same as the surrounding skin
Number of café au lait spots
A structure to collect information provided by the person or information provider in relation to the symptoms and difficulties they are presenting to the clinician
Base for recording the dates or intervals which apply
Generic encounter or progress note composition

Additional contextual detail to be applied to all compositions.

The period of care to which this composition belongs. This equates to the CONTSYS concept and repesents an admisitrative or contractual spell of care, involving a specific instiution or care provider.
The identifier of the departmental period of care to which this Composition belongs.
Portlet ID from which stores the information where was the composition saved.

ID časa zdravljenja, ki mu pripada ta composition. This equates to the CONTSYS concept and repesents an admisitrative or contractual spell of care, involving a specific instiution or care provider.(en)
ID časa zdravljenja na oddelku, ki mu pripada ta composition.
ID portleta v katerem so shranjene informacije o shranjenom composition-u.
